inline-block.p: manual sizing (works with any of the above bracket types)
alternative syntax; robust and more LaTeX-friendly

Math.text: absent rightarrow evaluatedat@((sum _ x) ^ x, 0, infinity)
absent rightarrow evaluatedat@((sum _ x) ^ x, 0, infinity)

tr.td: order symbol; automatic sizing and space handling
note: \dp is a protected TeX primitive

Math.text: absent rightarrow gradient@(Psi + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow gradient@(Psi + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow divergence@(a + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow divergence@(a + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow curl@(a + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow curl@(a + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow laplacian@(Psi + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)
absent rightarrow laplacian@(Psi + (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)

tr.td: can still use without an argument

Math.text: list@(sine@(1 / (x * x)), sine@(x) * delimited-[]@(1 / (x * x)), (power@(sine, x))@(1 / (x * x)), sine@(1 / (x * x)), sine@(x) * set@(1 / (x * x)))

→
tr
ρ
also \tr(\tall)
→
tr
(
A
x x
x
)
trace; same bracing as trig functions
residue; same bracing as trig functions

Math.text: list@(realport@(1 / (x * x)), realport@(1 / (x * x)), imagport@(1 / (x * x)), imagport@(1 / (x * x)))

tr.td: general quick quad text with argument

Math.text: absent rightarrow delimited-[]@([ word or phrase ])

tr.td:
complex conjugate; left and right \quad unless starred [\qcc*]
→
[ q c c * ]

left and right \quad unless starred [\qif*]
→
[ if ]

Math.text: absent rightarrow functionalderivative@(E - T * S, V)
\bra{\phi}\ket{\psi} rightarrow innerproduct@(phi, psi) * [ as opposed to ] * bra@(phi) * bra@(psi)

para.p: whereas a similar construction with higher-level macros will not contract in a robust manner
On the other hand, the correct output can be generated by sticking to the fundamental commands,

inline-block.p: a star on either term in the contraction prohibits resizing

Math.tex: \displaystyle\verb|\ev*{\grande}{\tall}|\rightarrow\@CSYMBOL{expectationvalue}% \mathchoice{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\displaystyle\frac{1}{xx}$}}{\hbox{% \pagecolor{cyan}$\textstyle\frac{1}{xx}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\scriptstyle% \frac{1}{xx}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\scriptscriptstyle\frac{1}{xx}$}}% \mathchoice{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\displaystyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{\hbox{% \pagecolor{cyan}$\textstyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$% \scriptstyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\scriptscriptstyle A^{x^{% x}}_{x}$}}\mathchoice{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\displaystyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{% \hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\textstyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$% \scriptstyle A^{x^{x}}_{x}$}}{\hbox{\pagecolor{cyan}$\scriptscriptstyle A^{x^{% x}}_{x}$}}
Math.text: \ev*{\grande}{\tall} rightarrow expectationvalue@(1 / (x * x), (A ^ x ^ x) _ x, (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)

tr.td: single star does no resizing whatsoever
double star resizes based on all parts

Math.text: \mel*{n}{\grande}{\tall} rightarrow expectationvalue@(1 / (x * x), n, (A ^ x ^ x) _ x)

tr.td: single star does no resizing whatsoever
double star resizes based on all parts

Math.text: matrix[[matrix[[1, 0], [0, 1]], matrix[[x / y], [b]]], [matrix[[u + v + w + x + y + z, d]], e]]

tr.td: groups a set of matrix elements into a single object

inline-block.p: alternative syntax; robust and more LaTeX-friendly

tr.td:
elements of
× n n
identity matrix

elements of
× n m
matrix filled with
x

× n m
matrix filled with zeros

inline-block.p: specify up to eight diagonal or block diagonal elements

Math.text: \mqty(\dmat{1,2,3}) rightarrow matrix[[1, absent, absent], [absent, 2, absent], [absent, absent, 3]]

td.p: enter matrix elements for each block as a single diagonal element

Math.text: \mqty(\admat{1,2,3}) rightarrow matrix[[absent, absent, 1], [absent, 2, absent], [3, absent, absent]]
